document.docAuthor: Etnier, David A., Parker, Charles R., John T. Baxter, Jr., Long, Todd M. & Drive, News Sentinel
document.masterDocTitle: A review of the genus Agapetus Curtis (Trichoptera: Glossosomatidae) in eastern and central North America, with description of 12 new species

mods:titleInfo.mods:title: A review of the genus Agapetus Curtis (Trichoptera: Glossosomatidae) in eastern and central North America, with description of 12 new species

heading.emphasis:
Key to
Agapetus
males of eastern and central North America.

paragraph.keyLead:
1. Segment X ( Fig. 13a ), shaped like head of an ibis, beak pointing downward; inferior appendage shaped like a banana, extending posteriorly approximately half its length beyond the end of segment X ....................................
Agapetus ibis Etnier, Baxter, and Parker
n. sp. , p. 21

â€” Segment X not like an ibis; inferior appendage not banana-shaped, shorter than length of X or extending only slightly posteriad of X ...................................................................................... 2
2(1). Inferior appendage with length at least 4.5 times maximum depth ( Fig. 5 , 8 , 15 , 16 , 22 ) ........ 3
â€” Inferior appendage with length at most 4 times maximum depth ( Fig. 17, 18 ) ......................... 7

keyLead.keyStep:
4(3). Denticle near middle of inferior appendage (ventral view) in middle of narrow triangular shelf ( Fig. 5c ); preanal appendage ( Fig. 5b ) typically curved in dorsal view (concave outer margin) ...............................................
Agapetus baueri Etnier, Parker, and Baxter
n. sp. , p. 10
â€” Denticle near middle of inferior appendage at posterior end of broad, serrate, trapezoidal shelf ( Fig. 16c ); preanal appendage nearly straight in dorsal view ( Fig. 16a ) .................................... .............................................................................................
Agapetus jocassee Morse
, p. 25

paragraph.keyLead:
5(3). Inferior appendages markedly sinuate on outer margin, denticles approximately evenly spaced along inner margin ( Fig. 8c ) ....
Agapetus flinti Parker, Etnier, and Baxter
n. sp. , p. 14

â€” Inferior appendages with outer margins nearly straight or with apex curved, denticles unequally spaced on inner margin ( Figs 15c , 22c ) .................................................................................... 6

6(5). Inferior appendages ( Fig. 22c ) with proximal denticles close together, one slightly posterior and dorsal to the other; terminal denticle not darkly pigmented.
Agapetus pinatus Ross
, p. 35

â€” Inferior appendages ( Fig. 15c ) with proximal denticles rather widely spaced and all denticles darkly pigmented ........................................................................
Agapetus iridis Ross
, p. 24

7(2). Posterior portion of segment X truncate and vertical or nearly so, and with 3-15 large denticles or spines directed posteriad or dorsad ( Fig. 1 , 14 , 20 , 23 , 27 ) ...................................................... 8

â€” Posterior margin of segment X may have small serrae, but never with more than 2 large denticles or spines ( Fig. 4 , 24 ), or if so X is definitely not truncate ...................................................... 12

9(8). Denticles on posterior margin of X do not extend above dorsal margin of X ( Fig. 14 ); inferior appendage ( Fig. 14c ) with two denticles connected by a darkened ridge .................................... .....................................................................................................
Agapetus illini Ross
, p. 23

â€” Denticles on posterior margin of X extend well above dorsum of X ( Fig. 20 , 23 ); inferior appendage ( Fig. 20c , 23c ) with two denticles, not connected by darkened ridge ..................................... 10

10(9). Dorsal setae of preanal appendage normal, not nearly as thick as denticles on posterior margin of X ( Fig. 20a ); distal denticle of inferior appendage ( Fig. 20c ) on ventral margin; denticulate posterior arms of X not flexible and with denticles in a double row ........................................... ............................................................................................
Agapetus minutus Sibley
, p. 31

â€” Dorsal setae of preanal appendage as thick as denticles on posterior arms of X ( Fig. 23a ); distal denticle of inferior appendage ( Fig. 23c ) submarginal; denticulate posterior arms of X flexible and with denticles in a single row ............................................................................................... ...............................................
Agapetus ruiteri Parker, Etnier, and Baxter
n. sp. , p. 36

11(8). Posterior margin of X with 4-9 denticles; ventral margin of X curved ventrad on distal 1/4 ( Fig. 1a ) .................................................................................
Agapetus alabamensis Harris
, p. 4

â€” Posterior margin of X with only 3 denticles; ventral margin of X horizontal or curved dorsad on its distal 1/4 ( Fig. 27a ) .......
Agapetus tricornutus Etnier, Parker, and Baxter
n. sp. , p. 42

13(12). Inferior appendage with finger-like dorsal projection ( Fig. 9a ) ...
Agapetus gelbae Ross
, p. 16
â€” Inferior appendage not finger-like ( Fig. 4a , 7a, 9a , 12a , 18a , 21a , 28a ) ................................... 14
â€” Inferior appendage with greatest depth near base, strongly tapered ( Fig. 21 ) ......................... 27

keyLead.keyStep: 15(14). Inferior appendage with greatest depth near posterior end, not rhomboid ( Fig. 12 , 24 , 26 ) .... 16

paragraph.keyLead: â€” Tip of inferior appendage slightly produced near mid-depth ( Fig. 12 , 24 ) ................................ 18

17(16). X with prominent rounded lobe apicoventrally; end of inferior appendage concave, occasionally nearly truncate ( Fig. 26a ) .........................................................
Agapetus tomus Ross
, p. 41

â€” X with narrow acute projection apicoventrally; end of inferior appendage deeply incised ( Fig 10a ) ..............................................
Agapetus harrisi Etnier, Parker, and Baxter
n. sp. , p. 17

18(16). Tip of inferior appendage concave both above and below median protrusion ( Fig. 12 ); each inferior appendage with two terminal denticles .........
Agapetus hessi Leonard and Leonard
, p. 20

â€” Tip of interior appendage convex below median protuberance ( Fig. 24 , 29 ); each inferior appendage with a single terminal denticle............................................................................................... 19

19(18). Tip of each ventral arm of X with one (rarely two) denticles ( Fig. 29a ); base of X with a laterally directed triangular denticle on each side ( Fig. 29c ) .................................................................... ....................................................................
Agapetus walkeri (Betten and Mosely)
, p. 46

â€” Tip of each ventral arm of X with a cluster of about 5 denticles ( Fig. 24a ); denticles typically absent near base of X ( Fig. 24c ) ........................
Agapetus spinosus Etnier and Way
, p. 38
â€” Inferior appendage with tip rounded ( Fig. 4a , 28a ), or truncate ( Fig. 18a ) .............................. 24

21(20). Inferior appendage nearly a perfect rhombus (anterior, posterior, dorsal, and ventral margins subequal, Fig. 6a , 7a ) ............................................................................................................. 22

â€” Inferior appendage with dorsal and ventral margins at least 1.5 times longer than anterior and posterior margins ( Fig. 11 , 17 ) ............................................................................................... 23

22(21). Segment X with terminal denticle curved upward at posterioventral corner ( Fig 6a ) .................. ...............................................................................................
Agapetus crasmus Ross
, p. 12

â€” Segment X with blunt tooth at posterioventral corner, then posterior margin straight and sloping anteriad ( Fig. 7 ) ........................................................
Agapetus diacanthus Edwards
, p. 13

23(21). Segment X (lateral) terminates in a darkened, long denticle, with a shorter, less darkened denticle above it ( Fig. 11a ) ..............
Agapetus hesperus Etnier, Baxter, and Parker
n. sp. , p. 18

â€” Segment X (lateral) terminates in a single denticle ( Fig. 17a ) ...................................................... ..........................................
Agapetus kirchneri Parker, Etnier, and Baxter
n. sp. , p. 27
24(20). Inferior appendage smoothly and rather symmetrically rounded at tip ( Fig. 4a , 19a , 28a )..... 25

â€” Inferior appendage with tip obliquely truncate, sloping down and back from posteriodorsal corner ( Fig. 18 ), known only from Arkansas ....................................
Agapetus medicus Ross
, p. 29

26(25). Segment X ( Fig 19a ) with posteriodorsal corner present; X terminating ventrally in a pointed projection ventral to ventral margin ........................................................................................... ....................................
Agapetus meridionalis Etnier, Parker, and Baxter
n. sp. , p. 30

â€” Segment X ( Fig. 4a ) lacking posteriodorsal corner; X terminating ventrally in a pointed projection level with ventral margin.....................................................
Agapetus avitus Edwards
, p. 8

27(14). Tip of X with 2 sharp denticles, each with length subequal to depth of preanal appendage ( Fig. 25 ) ...............................................
Agapetus stylifer Etnier, Baxter and Parker
n. sp. , p. 39
